text: Mr. Quarles, I think you may proceed whenever you're ready.
Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Mr. Quarles, I suppose the form the transaction took was largely guided by tax reasons, wasn't it?
There was no... as to my clients there was no choice involved.
Rather than the assets--
That is correct.
--Had it been of the assets, I suppose we wouldn't be here today.
I'm not certain that that's correct, Your Honor.
Mr. Quarles, do you think that United Housing Foundation against Forman was incorrectly decided by the Court?
On the facts of that case I do not.
May I just interrupt with one question?
I would say that 10(b)(5) and its requirements would apply, as this Court has held, in private, face-to-face negotiations as well as in negotiations which occur over the national--
And in every case in which any warranty in a contract with respect to the financial condition of the company is alleged to have been misleading or breached in some respect.
--Upon a demonstration of the proof of the requisite scienter and the other requirements of 10(b)(5), that would be correct.
Would it be co-extensive with common law fraud actions and breach of contract, or a little broader, I suppose?
It is substantially different, Your Honor.
But you still have your state common law action which you--
Washington... this Court said just two terms ago in Huddleston and McLean that the burden of proof upon a defrauded purchaser is preponderance of the evidence.
--Do you think there's anything in the legislative history that shows Congress thought it was giving federal jurisdiction for a suit like this?
Yes.
You rely on the interstate advertising and all that.
My case would be the same since they would have used an instrumentality of interstate commerce.
Very well, Mr. Quarles.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Well, Mr. Smith, I guess Congress did decide to include private transactions within the coverage of the anti-fraud provisions, didn't it?
That's correct, Your Honor.
Somewhere in your argument you will discuss the effect of your position on the Williams Act, I take it?

Well, the Williams Act which, as the Court is well aware, applies to tender offers, I submit evidences a very particular congressional intent to protect persons, non-sellers or investors in a tender offer situation.
Or 100 percent.
--Yes.
May I ask just to be sure I follow it as you go through, does that mean that you would agree there was a security if they had sold 40 percent of the company to these people.
--What it means is I would agree that there was a common enterprise and that that requirement would be satisfied, Justice Stevens.
Does it further mean you would agree there was a security in that event?

It means that the district court would have to take a very hard look whether that purchaser objectively, not subjective reliance but objectively under the circumstances of this particular case acquired control sufficient--
I said 40 percent.
--Yes.
Would that be a covered transaction, in your view?
The test would be whether or not the purchaser obtained control over the outcome of the investment.
You're saying he didn't.
Oh, in that instance I would say no.
You would say it was not a covered transaction.
Yes.
But if he sold 60 percent, it would have been a covered transaction.
I'm sorry.
I thought you did, too.
If the purchaser obtained 60 percent--
No.
--Yes.
And the seller retains the remaining 60 percent.
Yes.
Is the transaction covered or not?
I believe so.
It is?
Yes.
But it's not covered if he gets 51 percent.
Depending upon whether that 51 percent under the circumstances of the case provided actual control of the purchase.
But if it was a 40 percent price, we are clear that would be a security and all the economic realities would satisfy your standard.
Unless there was some sort of unique veto power or authority to run the business given to the purchaser.
No gimmicks.
Thank you.
No.
--I'd like to turn for a minute to the record below, because I think this Court should be quite clear what case it has before it, and I'm not sure it's the case as described by petitioner.
Do you think Forman, the opinion in Forman was influenced by the nature of what was sold and its utility?
I truly think not, Chief Justice.
It wasn't a sawmill type of an operation, was it?
That's correct, and it was a very unusual instrument.
Mr. Smith, may I ask you another question, just thinking of a little different kind of case?
Well, as I said earlier, Justice Stevens, I think when we get into publicly traded stock, in all candor, there is an interest exhibited by Congress in the '33 and '34 acts that--
So your argument really doesn't apply to publicly traded securities at all.
--Conceptually the logic's identical, but I think there might be good reasons that this Court should decide to draw the line with private transactions.
I see.
Now, there's something else about this Howey test, this economic realities test which I submit is very important in the Court's resolution of this case.
Why didn't you insist on an assets transaction... tax purposes?
I think... quite admittedly, Your Honor, I think in the negotiations my client wanted for tax reasons to have it be a stock transaction.
Usually the seller does, and the buyer wants the assets.
Yes.
Well, don't you think that ten cases on this subject with five each way apparently has been a burden on the federal courts that was avoidable if there had been a single rule?
--I certainly do.
So the time has come for us to make a single rule, hasn't it?
It certainly has.
Do you have two minutes remaining, Mr. Quarles.
Thank you, Your Honor.
Thank you, gentlemen.
